segment.source: 4662(S, F) An operation was performed on an object.
segment.target: 4662(S, F) An operation was performed on an object.

segment.source: Describes security event 4662(S, F) An operation was performed on an object.
segment.target: Describes security event 4662(S, F) An operation was performed on an object.

segment.source: 4662(S, F): An operation was performed on an object.
segment.target: 4662(S, F): An operation was performed on an object.

segment.source: This event generates every time when an operation was performed on an Active Directory object.
segment.target: This event generates every time when an operation was performed on an Active Directory object.

segment.source: This event generates only if appropriate SACL was set for Active Directory object and performed operation meets this SACL.
segment.target: This event generates only if appropriate SACL was set for Active Directory object and performed operation meets this SACL.

segment.source: If operation failed then Failure event will be generated.
segment.target: If operation failed then Failure event will be generated.

segment.source: You will get one 4662 for each operation type which was performed.
segment.target: You will get one 4662 for each operation type which was performed.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Object Server Type = UnicodeString: has “DS” value for this event.
segment.target: Object Server Type = UnicodeString: has “DS” value for this event.

segment.source: Object Type Type = UnicodeString: type or class of the object that was accessed.
segment.target: Object Type Type = UnicodeString: type or class of the object that was accessed.

segment.source: Some of the common Active Directory object types and classes are:
segment.target: Some of the common Active Directory object types and classes are:

segment.source: For all possible values of Object Type open Active Directory Schema snap-in (see how to enable this snap-in: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Cc755885(v=WS.10).aspx) and navigate to Active Directory SchemaClasses.
segment.target: For all possible values of Object Type open Active Directory Schema snap-in (see how to enable this snap-in: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Cc755885(v=WS.10).aspx) and navigate to Active Directory SchemaClasses.

segment.source: Object Name Type = UnicodeString: distinguished name of the object that was accessed.
segment.target: Object Name Type = UnicodeString: distinguished name of the object that was accessed.

segment.source: Note The LDAP API references an LDAP object by its distinguished name (DN).
segment.target: Note The LDAP API references an LDAP object by its distinguished name (DN).

segment.source: A DN is a sequence of relative distinguished names (RDN) connected by commas.
segment.target: A DN is a sequence of relative distinguished names (RDN) connected by commas.

segment.source: An RDN is an attribute with an associated value in the form attribute=value; .
segment.target: An RDN is an attribute with an associated value in the form attribute=value; .

segment.source: These are examples of RDNs attributes:
segment.target: These are examples of RDNs attributes:

segment.source: Handle ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal value of a handle to Object Name.
segment.target: Handle ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal value of a handle to Object Name.

segment.source: This field can help you correlate this event with other events that might contain the same Handle ID, for example, “4661: A handle to an object was requested.”
segment.target: This field can help you correlate this event with other events that might contain the same Handle ID, for example, “4661: A handle to an object was requested.”

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “0x0”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “0x0”.

segment.source: Operation Type Type = UnicodeString: the type of operation which was performed on an object.
segment.target: Operation Type Type = UnicodeString: the type of operation which was performed on an object.

segment.source: Typically has “Object Access” value for this event.
segment.target: Typically has “Object Access” value for this event.

segment.source: Accesses Type = UnicodeString: the type of access used for the operation.
segment.target: Accesses Type = UnicodeString: the type of access used for the operation.

segment.source: Active Directory Access Codes and Rights.”
segment.target: Active Directory Access Codes and Rights.”

segment.source: Access Mask Type = HexInt32: hexadecimal mask for the type of access used for the operation.
segment.target: Access Mask Type = HexInt32: hexadecimal mask for the type of access used for the operation.

segment.source: Active Directory Access Codes and Rights.”
segment.target: Active Directory Access Codes and Rights.”

segment.source: The right to create child objects of the object.
segment.target: The right to create child objects of the object.

segment.source: The right to delete child objects of the object.
segment.target: The right to delete child objects of the object.

segment.source: The right to list child objects of this object.
segment.target: The right to list child objects of this object.

segment.source: The right to perform an operation controlled by a validated write access right.
segment.target: The right to perform an operation controlled by a validated write access right.

segment.source: The right to read properties of the object.
segment.target: The right to read properties of the object.

segment.source: The right to write properties of the object.
segment.target: The right to write properties of the object.

segment.source: Delete all children of this object, regardless of the permissions of the children.
segment.target: Delete all children of this object, regardless of the permissions of the children.

segment.source: It is indicates that “Use Delete Subtree server control” check box was checked during deletion.
segment.target: It is indicates that “Use Delete Subtree server control” check box was checked during deletion.

segment.source: This operation means that all objects within the subtree, including all delete-protected objects, will be deleted.
segment.target: This operation means that all objects within the subtree, including all delete-protected objects, will be deleted.

segment.source: The right to list a particular object.
segment.target: The right to list a particular object.

segment.source: Access allowed only after extended rights checks supported by the object are performed.
segment.target: Access allowed only after extended rights checks supported by the object are performed.

segment.source: The right to perform an operation controlled by an extended access right.
segment.target: The right to perform an operation controlled by an extended access right.

segment.source: The right to delete the object.
segment.target: The right to delete the object.

segment.source: DELETE also generated when object was moved.
segment.target: DELETE also generated when object was moved.

segment.source: The right to read data from the security descriptor of the object, not including the data in the SACL.
segment.target: The right to read data from the security descriptor of the object, not including the data in the SACL.

segment.source: The right to modify the discretionary access-control list (DACL) in the object security descriptor.
segment.target: The right to modify the discretionary access-control list (DACL) in the object security descriptor.

segment.source: The right to assume ownership of the object.
segment.target: The right to assume ownership of the object.

segment.source: The user must be an object trustee.
segment.target: The user must be an object trustee.

segment.source: The user cannot transfer the ownership to other users.
segment.target: The user cannot transfer the ownership to other users.

segment.source: The right to use the object for synchronization.
segment.target: The right to use the object for synchronization.

segment.source: This enables a thread to wait until the object is in the signaled state.
segment.target: This enables a thread to wait until the object is in the signaled state.

segment.source: The right to get or set the SACL in the object security descriptor.
segment.target: The right to get or set the SACL in the object security descriptor.

segment.source: The right to read permissions on this object, read all the properties on this object, list this object name when the parent container is listed, and list the contents of this object if it is a container.
segment.target: The right to read permissions on this object, read all the properties on this object, list this object name when the parent container is listed, and list the contents of this object if it is a container.

segment.source: The right to read permissions on this object, write all the properties on this object, and perform all validated writes to this object.
segment.target: The right to read permissions on this object, write all the properties on this object, and perform all validated writes to this object.

segment.source: The right to read permissions on, and list the contents of, a container object.
segment.target: The right to read permissions on, and list the contents of, a container object.

segment.source: The right to create or delete child objects, delete a subtree, read and write properties, examine child objects and the object itself, add and remove the object from the directory, and read or write with an extended right.
segment.target: The right to create or delete child objects, delete a subtree, read and write properties, examine child objects and the object itself, add and remove the object from the directory, and read or write with an extended right.

segment.source: Active Directory Access Codes and Rights.
segment.target: Active Directory Access Codes and Rights.

segment.source: Properties Type = UnicodeString: first part is the type of access that was used.
segment.target: Properties Type = UnicodeString: first part is the type of access that was used.

segment.source: Typically has the same value as Accesses field.
segment.target: Typically has the same value as Accesses field.

segment.source: Second part is a tree of GUID values of Active Directory classes or property sets, for which operation was performed.
segment.target: Second part is a tree of GUID values of Active Directory classes or property sets, for which operation was performed.

segment.source:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.
segment.target:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.

segment.source: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.
segment.target: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.

segment.source: To translate this GUID, use the following procedure:
segment.target: To translate this GUID, use the following procedure:

segment.source: Perform the following LDAP search using LDP.exe tool:
segment.target: Perform the following LDAP search using LDP.exe tool:

segment.source: Perform the following operations with the GUID before using it in a search request:
segment.target: Perform the following operations with the GUID before using it in a search request:

segment.source: We have this GUID to search for: bf967a86-0de6-11d0-a285-00aa003049e2
segment.target: We have this GUID to search for: bf967a86-0de6-11d0-a285-00aa003049e2

segment.source: For each of these 3 sections you need to change (Invert) the order of bytes, like this 867a96bf-e60d-d011
segment.target: For each of these 3 sections you need to change (Invert) the order of bytes, like this 867a96bf-e60d-d011

segment.source: Add the last 2 sections without transformation: 867a96bf-e60d-d011-a285-00aa003049e2
segment.target: Add the last 2 sections without transformation: 867a96bf-e60d-d011-a285-00aa003049e2

segment.source: Sometimes GUID refers to pre-defined Active Directory Property Sets, you can find GUID (Rights-GUID field), “property set name” and details here: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms683990(v=vs.85).aspx.
segment.target: Sometimes GUID refers to pre-defined Active Directory Property Sets, you can find GUID (Rights-GUID field), “property set name” and details here: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms683990(v=vs.85).aspx.

segment.source: Here is an example of decoding of Properties field:
segment.target: Here is an example of decoding of Properties field:

segment.source: Parameter 1 Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.
segment.target: Parameter 1 Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.

segment.source: Parameter 2 Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.
segment.target: Parameter 2 Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.

segment.source: For 4662(S, F): An operation was performed on an object.
segment.target: For 4662(S, F): An operation was performed on an object.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: If you need to monitor operations attempts to specific Active Directory classes, monitor for Object Type field with specific class name.
segment.target: If you need to monitor operations attempts to specific Active Directory classes, monitor for Object Type field with specific class name.

segment.source: For example, we recommend that you monitor all operations attempts to domainDNS class.
segment.target: For example, we recommend that you monitor all operations attempts to domainDNS class.

segment.source: If you need to monitor operations attempts to specific Active Directory objects, monitor for Object Name field with specific object name.
segment.target: If you need to monitor operations attempts to specific Active Directory objects, monitor for Object Name field with specific object name.

segment.source: For example, we recommend that you monitor all operations attempts to “CN=AdminSDHolder,CN=System,DC=domain,DC=com” object.
segment.target: For example, we recommend that you monitor all operations attempts to “CN=AdminSDHolder,CN=System,DC=domain,DC=com” object.

segment.source: Some access types are more important to monitor, for example:
segment.target: Some access types are more important to monitor, for example:

segment.source: You can decide to monitor these (or one of these) access types for specific Active Directory objects.
segment.target: You can decide to monitor these (or one of these) access types for specific Active Directory objects.

segment.source: To do so, monitor for Accesses field with specific access type.
segment.target: To do so, monitor for Accesses field with specific access type.

segment.source: If you need to monitor operations attempts to specific Active Directory properties, monitor for Properties field with specific property GUID.
segment.target: If you need to monitor operations attempts to specific Active Directory properties, monitor for Properties field with specific property GUID.

segment.source: Do not forget that Failure attempts are also very important to audit.
segment.target: Do not forget that Failure attempts are also very important to audit.

segment.source: Decide where you want to monitor Failure attempts based on previous recommendations.
segment.target: Decide where you want to monitor Failure attempts based on previous recommendations.
